traits.title: Parietal depression (left)
traits.location: The parietal bone between the superior temporal line and the sagittal surface.
notes: The contour of the parietal bones is most easily assessed in a posterior view. However, depressions can often be seen in a superior view, particularly when the bone where the depression is located is particularly thin.
Depressions can be subtle, asymmetric, and may occur unilaterally.

Robust parietal bosses, well-developed temporal lines, sagittal keeling, or a combination of these features can cause parietal bones to appear depressed. Take care to differentiate these features from parietal bones that are depressed relative to the normal contour of the parietal bone.
Well-healed cranial trauma (unilateral or bilateral) is distinctively different than parietal thinning and should not be scored.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The parietal bone contour is rounded or flattened, but not dpressed.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Posterior view. The parietal bones are rounded. (ID# 1566)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Posterior view. The right parietal bone is flattened. (ID# 1831)

scores.title: present
scores.description: A portion of the parietal bone is slightly depressed (concave) relative to its normal countour. A depression is most often a rounded or oval area located on the middle to posterior portion of the parietal bone. Less typically, the depression can be expressed as a long groove, two or more centimeters wide, just superior to the temporal line.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Posterior view. Subtle bilateral depressions. (ID# 2719)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Posterior. Bilateral depressions (ID# 1384)

images.caption: Posterior. Bilateral asymmetric depressions (ID# 2501)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Posterior. Bilateral depressions. (ID# 2501)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Superior. Bilateral depressions. The depressions are distinct in both color and contour. (ID# 2501)

images.title: Present

traits.title: Occipital condyle lipping (left)
traits.location: The edges of the articulation surfaces of the occipital condyles.
notes: The irregular lipping scored here occurs on the borders on the condyle and it should not be confused with the irregular roughening and bony growths that often occur in the area surrounding the condyle.

scores.title: absent (<50%)
scores.description: Lipping does not occur around 50% or more of the articulation surface.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Some lipping is present, but less than 50% of the condyle has >= 1mm of lipping. (ID# 1656)

scores.title: present (>=50%)
scores.description: Easily visible, irregular bony lipping must extend outward or inferiorly for >= 1mm for >= 50% of >= 75% of the circumference of the condyle. The remainder of the condyle often has a low and narrow, but regular, lip that projects < 1mm.

traits.title: Spheno-occipital synchondrosis
traits.location: The region where the basilar portion of the occipital bone and the sphenoid meet.
notes: The overwhelming majority of individuals will be fully fused.
Postmortem breaks in this region may imitate an open or partially fused synchondrosis.
Small vascular impressions and surface irregularities can exist on the external surface of a closed spehnooccipital synchondrosis. These grooves should not be mistaken for incomplete fusion.

scores.title: open
scores.description: Any gap between the sphenoid and occipital visible on the external surface of the basicranium.

images.title: Open
images.caption: The synchondrosis is completely open with small foramina visible on the basioccipital posterior to the open synchondrosis. (ID# 1758)

scores.title: closed
scores.description: There is no evidence of a transversely oriented groove transversley oriented groove where the occipital and sphenoid bones meet.

images.title: Closed
images.caption: The synchondosis is completely fused, but a postmortem break is present in this area. (ID# 2721)

images.title: Closed
images.caption: Small vascular impressions that can occur in this area (circled) should not be confused with an open, or partially open, synchondrosis. (ID# 1826)
Location of spheno-occipital synchondrosis. (ID# 1758)

traits.title: C1 lipping
traits.description: 1st cervical vertebra dens articulation surface lipping
traits.location: The edges of the articulation surface for the dens (odontoid process) on the posterior surface of the anterior arch of the first cervical vertebra (atlas)
notes: The bone growth around the articulation facet resembles the lipping seen at other synovial joint margins.
The present category is typically easily identifiable as soon as you pick up the bone. If close inspection is required, then the trait is usually scored as absent.

scores.title: absent (<50%)
scores.description: It is common to have a rounded to sharp, distinct, but narrow and regular, bony elevation surrounding part of all of the facet. This raised rim can sometimes take on a somewhat irregular appearance, but does not satisfy the length of extension criteria for lipping.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The articulation facet does not have distinct margins. No lipping is present. (ID# 1758)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Narrow raised rim that does not meet the criteria for lipping to be present. (ID# 2301)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Small raised rim inferiorly. No lipping is present. (ID# 1491)

scores.title: present (>=50%)
scores.description: Irregular bony growth extends superiorly, inferiorly, or laterally >= 1.5mm from the joint margin, bordering >= 50% of the articulation surface.

images.title: Present
images.caption: At least 1.mm of lipping extends outward around >= 50% of the margin of the articular facet. (ID# 1626)

images.title: Present
images.caption: More than 1.5mm of lipping extends outward from around more than half of the articular facet. (ID# 1365)
Location of the borders of the C1 articular facet.

traits.title: C1 eburnation
traits.location: The articulation surface for the dens on the anterior arch of the first cervical vertebra.
notes: C1 eburnation is the same as that often seen on the articulation surfaces of other synovial joints.
Any bony growth around the articulation surface should be treated as an extended joint surface. If eburnation is found only on this lipping, it should still be scored as present.
If the bone is covered in preservative, dirt, or grease, this feature is often not observable.
It is possible to have eburnation without being scored as >= 50% lipped.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: No eburnation exists on either the articulation facet or the additional bone surrounding it.

scores.title: present
scores.description: Eburnation is characterized an area of shiny, smooth, dense-looking bone on either the joint surface or any lipping surrounding it. A single spot of eburnation is sufficient to be scored as present.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Lipped with extensive eburnation on articular surface. (ID# 2022)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Extensive eburnation on articular surface and bordering portions of the surrounding bone growth. (ID# 1365)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Extensive eburnation on both the original articular surface and surrounding lipping. (ID# 1411)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Extensive eburnation of articular surface and surrounding irregular lipping. (ID# 2668)
Location of dens articular facet.

traits.title: L1 spinous process flattening
traits.location: Dorsal end of the spinous process of the first lumbar vertebra is examined.
notes: The change from rounded/flat to ossified results from the ossification of ligaments that eventually can bridge the spinous processes of the vertebrae.

scores.title: smooth (convex/round)
scores.description: The spinous process of L1 is smooth and round, as seen in a lateral view, with no ligament ossification.

images.title: Round
images.caption: The spinous process is rounded and the bone is smooth. (ID# 2438)

images.title: Round
images.caption: The shape of the spinous process is slightly rounded, but smooth. (ID# 2723)

scores.title: smooth (flat)
scores.description: The spinous process of L1 is smooth and flat, with no ligament ossification, when viewed laterally. The surface texture of the spinous process is typically the same as in the round category.

images.title: Flat
images.caption: Image reversed. (ID# 1731)

scores.title: ligament ossification (any shape)
scores.description: The process is ossified when >= 1mm of ossified ligaments are present, cranially, caudally, laterally (around the edges), or posteriorly. If ossified, the overall shape of the process is not important.

images.title: Ossified
images.caption: More than 1mm of ossification on a rounded surface. (ID# 1701)

images.title: Ossified
images.caption: Irregular ossification on a round surface. Image reversed. (ID# 1378)

images.title: Ossified
images.caption: Ossification on a flat surface. (ID# 2679)

images.title: Ossified
images.caption: Image reversed. (ID# 1496)

images.title: Ossified
images.caption: Ossified ligaments project for >= 1mm superiorly and inferior. Image reversed. (ID# 1472)
Scoring location on spinous process in lateral view.

traits.title: L1 superior epiphyseal ring fusion
traits.description: L1 superior body surface - epiphyseal ring fusion
traits.location: Superior (cranial) surface of the first lumbar vertebrae.
notes: The superior and inferior epiphyseal rings of L1 and L5 are scored separately. They often have different scores when rings are in the process of fusing.
Remnant lines may appear anywhere along the margins of the vertebral body. Typically, the most lateral portions are latest to fuse.

scores.title: not fused (NF)
scores.description: The epiphyseal ring is not fused.

images.title: Not fused
images.caption: Superior view of the an L5 vertebra without epiphyseal ring fusion. (ID# 1125)

images.title: Not fused
images.caption: Anterior view of the an L5 vertebra without epiphyseal ring fusion. (ID# 1125)

scores.title: partially fused (PF)
scores.description: Some, but not all, of the epiphyseal ring is fused to the body. Often one or more pieces of the partially fused ring are broken off the vertebral body. If the debts of the groove between the ring and body visible on the ventral portion of the vertebral body are open, the trait is scored as partial fusion.

images.title: Partially fused
images.caption: a) Inferior oblique and b) inferior views of a partially fused epiphyseal ring. Most, but not all, of the epiphyseal ring is fused. (ID# 2199)

images.title: Partially fused (a)
images.caption: a) Inferior epiphysis is partially fused. The bottom of the groove between the epiphyseal ring and body is open, and the margins are sharp. Specimen number removed from image. (ID# 1913)

scores.title: remnant line (RL)
scores.description: A remnant line (RL) of any length is present when the epiphyseal ring is completely fused, but not fully integrated into the anterior surface of the body. The renmant line is a noticeable, but shallow, groove located 1-2 mm from the articular surface. The groove has rounded borders and the bottom is clearly visible (fused).

images.title: Remnant line (b)
images.caption: b) The superior epiphysis is a remnant line. The bottom of the groove is easily visible, hence the ring is fully and firmly attached to the body. Specimen number removed from image. (ID# 1913)

scores.title: fully fused (FF)
scores.description: There is no sign of epiphyseal fusion.

traits.title: L1 superior surface morphology
traits.description: L1 superior body surface - surface morphology
traits.location:
The anterior portion of the inferior surface, 1cm interior to he vertebral border, including the epiphyseal ring.

The anterior half is the portion anterior to the widest portion of the vertebral body, excluding the central portion of the face.
notes: Schmorl's Nodes are not scored; they can render a vertebra not scorable.
Vertebrae altered through infection, trauma, or collapse should not be scored.

scores.title: billows (GF)
scores.description: At least half (1/2) of the scoring area is covered by rounded radiating billows (low, rounded ridges), 10mm or more of which along the anterior portion of the vertebra must be well-defined. Individual billows are 2-3mm wide, as measured from the depths of the grooves on either side of the raised area.

images.title: Billows
images.caption: Deep billows cover the entire scoring area. (ID# 1758)

images.title: Billows
images.caption: Well-defined billows cover almost all of the scoring area. Deep channels (grooves) separate the rounded hills. (ID# 1758)

images.title: Billows
images.caption: Well-defined billows cover more than 1/3 of the scoring area under a fused epiphyseal ring. (ID# 2199)

images.title: Billows
images.caption: Borderline case. Billows cover >= 1/3 of the scoring area. At least 10mm of those on the right side of the scoring area are well-defined with clearly visible crests and valleys. (ID# 2438)

scores.title: flat
scores.description: The vertebral body has a flat appearance. Sometimes extremely low elevations (residual billows) without well-defined peaks and flanking valleys or narrow striations may be present; the surface is still classified as flat.

images.title: Flat
images.caption: Flat surface with faint residual billows (left side of the scoring area) and linear exostoses. (ID# 2438)

images.title: Flat
images.caption: Flat surface with scattered microporosity. No microporous pitting or macroporosity is present. (ID# 2303)

scores.title: porous (macro or pits)
scores.description:
At least one-third (1/3) of the scoring area is covered with either holes greater than 1mm in diameter (macropores) or with a proliferation of micropores forming concentrated areas of pitting.

Pitting commonly occurs on the epiphyseal ring, but can occur anywhere within 10mm of the vertebral border. A surface with a number of non-contiguous micropores is scored as flat.

images.title: Porous
images.caption: Microporous pitting is present on the epiphyseal ring that covers >= 1/3 of the scoring area. (ID# 1438)

images.title: Porous
images.caption: Microporous pitting covers >= 1/3 of the scoring area. (ID# 1959)

images.title: Porous
images.caption: Microporosity and macroporosity cover the entire scoring area. (ID# 1762)

images.title: Porous
images.caption: Macroporosity covers essentially all of the scoring area. (ID# 2678)

Surface morphology scoring area (shaded area). Shaded area indicates the region 1cm interior to the edge of the body, including the epiphyseal ring. Dotted line indicates the part scored (anterior to the widest part of the body).

images.title: Billows
images.caption: Well-defined billows cover almost all of the scoring area. Deep channels (grooves) separate the rounded hills. (ID# 1758)

images.title: Billows
images.caption: Well-defined billows cover more than 1/3 of the scoring area under a fused epiphyseal ring. (ID# 2199)

images.title: Billows
images.caption: Borderline case. Billows cover >= 1/3 of the scoring area. At least 10mm of those on the right side of the scoring area are well-defined with clearly visible crests and valleys. (ID# 2438)

scores.title: flat
scores.description: The vertebral body has a flat appearance. Sometimes extremely low elevations (residual billows) without well-defined peaks and flanking valleys or narrow striations may be present; the surface is still classified as flat.

images.title: Flat
images.caption: Flat surface with faint residual billows (left side of the scoring area) and linear exostoses. (ID# 2438)

images.title: Flat
images.caption: Flat surface with scattered microporosity. No microporous pitting or macroporosity is present. (ID# 2303)

scores.title: porous (macro or pits)
scores.description:
At least one-third (1/3) of the scoring area is covered with either holes greater than 1mm in diameter (macropores) or with a proliferation of micropores forming concentrated areas of pitting.

Pitting commonly occurs on the epiphyseal ring, but can occur anywhere within 10mm of the vertebral border. A surface with a number of non-contiguous micropores is scored as flat.

images.title: Porous
images.caption: Microporous pitting is present on the epiphyseal ring that covers >= 1/3 of the scoring area. (ID# 1438)

images.title: Porous
images.caption: Microporous pitting covers >= 1/3 of the scoring area. (ID# 1959)

images.title: Porous
images.caption: Microporosity and macroporosity cover the entire scoring area. (ID# 1762)

images.title: Porous
images.caption: Macroporosity covers essentially all of the scoring area. (ID# 2678)

Surface morphology scoring area (shaded area). Shaded area indicates the region 1cm interior to the edge of the body, including the epiphyseal ring. Dotted line indicates the part scored (anterior to the widest part of the body).

traits.title: L5 inferior epiphyseal ring fusion
traits.description: L5 inferior body surface - epiphyseal ring fusion
traits.location: Inferior (caudal) surface of the fifth lumbar vertebrae.
notes: The superior and inferior epiphyseal rings of L1 and L5 are scored separately. They often have different scores when rings are in the process of fusing.
Remnant lines may appear anywhere along the margins of the vertebral body. Typically, the most lateral portions are latest to fuse.

scores.title: not fused (NF)
scores.description: The epiphyseal ring is not fused.

images.title: Not fused
images.caption: Superior view of the an L5 vertebra without epiphyseal ring fusion. (ID# 1125)

images.title: Not fused
images.caption: Anterior view of the an L5 vertebra without epiphyseal ring fusion. (ID# 1125)

scores.title: partially fused (PF)
scores.description: Some, but not all, of the epiphyseal ring is fused to the body. Often one or more pieces of the partially fused ring are broken off the vertebral body. If the debts of the groove between the ring and body visible on the ventral portion of the vertebral body are open, the trait is scored as partial fusion.

images.title: Partially fused
images.caption: a) Inferior oblique and b) inferior views of a partially fused epiphyseal ring. Most, but not all, of the epiphyseal ring is fused. (ID# 2199)

images.title: Partially fused (a)
images.caption: a) Inferior epiphysis is partially fused. The bottom of the groove between the epiphyseal ring and body is open, and the margins are sharp. Specimen number removed from image. (ID# 1913)

scores.title: remnant line (RL)
scores.description: A remnant line (RL) of any length is present when the epiphyseal ring is completely fused, but not fully integrated into the anterior surface of the body. The renmant line is a noticeable, but shallow, groove located 1-2 mm from the articular surface. The groove has rounded borders and the bottom is clearly visible (fused).

images.title: Remnant line (b)
images.caption: b) The superior epiphysis is a remnant line. The bottom of the groove is easily visible, hence the ring is fully and firmly attached to the body. Specimen number removed from image. (ID# 1913)

scores.title: fully fused (FF)
scores.description: There is no sign of epiphyseal fusion.

traits.title: L5 inferior surface morphology
traits.description: L5 inferior body surface - surface morphology
traits.location:
The anterior portion of the inferior surface, 1cm interior to he vertebral border, including the epiphyseal ring.

The anterior half is the portion anterior to the widest portion of the vertebral body, excluding the central portion of the face.
notes: Schmorl's Nodes are not scored; they can render a vertebra not scorable.
Vertebrae altered through infection, trauma, or collapse should not be scored.

scores.title: billows (GF)
scores.description: At least half (1/2) of the scoring area is covered by rounded radiating billows (low, rounded ridges), 10mm or more of which along the anterior portion of the vertebra must be well-defined. Individual billows are 2-3mm wide, as measured from the depths of the grooves on either side of the raised area.

traits.title: L5 superior margin shape
traits.location: The anterior 20mm (10mm either side of the midline) of the superior margins of the fifth lumbar vertebra.
notes: It is often easier to score the inferior margin by turning the vertebra over to view the margin in an inferior to superior direction.
If the epiphyseal ring is unfused, the margin should be sored as round.

scores.title: round
scores.description: The ventral margin is smooth and rounded. The margin transitions without interruption from the superior surface to the anterior surface.

images.title: Round
images.caption: Lateral view of a superior margin. The superior surface merges with the anterior face in a smooth, continuous arc. (ID# 2454)

images.title: Round
images.caption: Anterior-oblique view of a superior margin. The superior surface merges with the anterior face in a smooth, continuous arc. (ID# 2454)

images.title: Round
images.caption: Both the superior and inferior margins are round. Image reversed. (ID# 2182)

scores.title: sharp
scores.description: A reasonably sharp edge (angle) is present between the articular and anterior surfaces. The edge feels sharp when rubbed against the sensitive skin on the palmar surface of the finger joints.

images.title: Sharp (a) & lipped (b)
images.caption: Lateral view of a sharp inferior margin (a) and a lipped superior margin (b). Inferiorly, the anterior surface of the body meets the inferior articular surface at an angle, not a smooth curve. (ID# 2529)

scores.title: lipped
scores.description: The margin has any amount of bony lipping. Lipping typically occurs on an otherwise angular margin. If lipping has resulted in fusion to another vertebral element, it should be scored as lipped.

images.title: Sharp (a) & lipped (b)
images.caption: Anterior-oblique view of a sharp inferior margin (a) and a lipped superior margin (b). Inferiorly, the anterior surface of the body meets the inferior articular surface at an angle, not a smooth curve. (ID# 2529)

images.title: Lipped
images.caption: Anterior (a) and superior (b) views of a lipped superior margin. (ID# 2726)

images.title: Lipped
images.caption: Superior view of lipped superior margin. (ID# 2725)
Anterior 20mm (2cm) of the vertebral margin (superior margin shown). Superior and inferior margins are scored independently.

traits.title: L5 inferior margin shape
traits.location: The anterior 20mm (10mm either side of the midline) of the inferior margins of the fifth lumbar vertebra.
notes: It is often easier to score the inferior margin by turning the vertebra over to view the margin in an inferior to superior direction.
If the epiphyseal ring is unfused, the margin should be sored as round.

scores.title: round
scores.description: The ventral margin is smooth and rounded. The margin transitions without interruption from the superior surface to the anterior surface.

images.title: Round
images.caption: Lateral view of a superior margin. The superior surface merges with the anterior face in a smooth, continuous arc. (ID# 2454)

images.title: Round
images.caption: Anterior-oblique view of a superior margin. The superior surface merges with the anterior face in a smooth, continuous arc. (ID# 2454)

images.title: Round
images.caption: Both the superior and inferior margins are round. Image reversed. (ID# 2182)

scores.title: sharp
scores.description: A reasonably sharp edge (angle) is present between the articular and anterior surfaces. The edge feels sharp when rubbed against the sensitive skin on the palmar surface of the finger joints.

images.caption: Lateral view of a sharp inferior margin (a) and a lipped superior margin (b). Inferiorly, the anterior surface of the body meets the inferior articular surface at an angle, not a smooth curve. (ID# 2529)

scores.title: lipped

images.title: Sharp (a) & lipped (b)
images.caption: Anterior-oblique view of a sharp inferior margin (a) and a lipped superior margin (b). Inferiorly, the anterior surface of the body meets the inferior articular surface at an angle, not a smooth curve. (ID# 2529)

images.caption: Anterior (a) and superior (b) views of a lipped superior margin. (ID# 2726)

images.title: Lipped
images.caption: Superior view of lipped superior margin. (ID# 2725)
Anterior 20mm (2cm) of the vertebral margin (superior margin shown). Superior and inferior margins are scored independently.

traits.title: S1 margin shape
traits.location: Middle 20mm of the anterior (ventral) superior edge of the first sacral body (S1)
notes: The difference between rounded and sharp must be adjusted for size. It is common for particularly small individuals to have a margin that feels sharper than normal, but that is still round.
The distinction between the round and sharp categories can be felt as well as seen -- the former is best donewith the sensitive part of the palmar surface of a finger joint.
The bone should be scored as lipped if fusion to the last lumbar vertebra has occurred as the result of bony lipping.

scores.title: round
scores.description: The (ventral) margin is smooth and rounded. The margin transitions without interruption from the superior to anterior surface.

images.title: Round
images.caption: Lateral-oblique (a) and anterior views (b, slight postmortem damage). The superior surface of S1 meets the anterior surface in a smooth, rounded curve. (ID# 2078)

images.title: Round
images.caption: Lateral-oblique view. Althrough less round, the suprerior articular surface of S1 merges smoothly with the anterior face of the sacrum. No distinctly sharp angle is present. (ID# 2438)

images.title: Round
images.caption: Anterior view. Althrough less round, the suprerior articular surface of S1 merges smoothly with the anterior face of the sacrum. No distinctly sharp angle is present. (ID# 2438)

images.title: Round
images.caption: Lateral-oblique (a) and anterior views (b). Althrough less round, the superior articular surface of S1 merges smoothly with the anterior face of the sacrum. No distinct sharp edge (angle) is present. (ID# 2727)

images.title: Round
images.caption: Oblique view of round margins. Image reversed. (ID# 1070)

scores.title: sharp
scores.description: A reasonably sharp edge (an angle) is present between the superior and anterior surfaces.

images.title: Sharp
images.caption: Oblique view of sharp margins. In sacrum, the anterior margin where the superior and anterior surfaces meet is a sharp angle. (ID# 1695)

scores.title: lipped
scores.description: The margin has any amount of bony lipping. Lipping is typically only found on an otherwise angular margin.

images.title: Lipped
images.caption: Superior-oblique view of a slightly lipped anterior margin, with significant lipping present lateral to the scoring area. The slight lipping occurs on an otherwise angular margin; any lipping is sufficient for a lipped score. (ID# 1477)

images.title: Lipped
images.caption: Anterior view of substantially lipped margin. (ID# 2040)

traits.title: S1-S2 fusion
traits.location: The anterior surface of the sacrum where the first two sacral bodies meet.
notes: A gap is considered present when there is an opening that extends into the space between the two sacral bodies.
Many specimens where vertebral shifts occur cannot be recorded.

scores.title: gap >= 10mm
scores.description: A gap more than 10mm in length is open without interruption.

images.title: Gap >= 10mm
images.caption: The joint between S1 and S2 is completely open. (ID# 2405)

images.title: Gap >= 10mm
images.caption: The joint between S1 and S2 has started to fuse internally but is still visible along its entire length. More than 10mm of the space is open. (ID# 2464)

images.title: Gap >= 10mm
images.caption: The lateral portions of the joint have started to fuse externally but more than 10mm of the joint is open. (ID# 1804)

images.title: Gap >= 10mm
images.caption: An opening just over 10mm in length is present. (ID# 2438)

scores.title: gap < 10mm
scores.description: A gap less than 10mm is present.

images.title: Gap < 10mm
images.caption: A gap of less than 10mm is present. In some individuals, small gaps will persist for most or all of adulthood. (ID# 2163)

scores.title: closed
scores.description: There is no evidence of a gap between the anterior sacral bodies.

traits.title: Sacral "Elbow"
traits.location: The anterior (ventral) surface of the sacrum -- the angle of interest is located between S2 and S4, including the joints between them.
notes: Both anterior and lateral views are typically necessary to evaluate a sacral "elbow".
Sacral fractures most often occur in osteoporotic individuals. However, lower than normal bone mineral density is not a requirement for this feature to be scored as present.
The angle of interest most often occurs on S3, S4, or the joint between them, but can occur slightly higher or lower.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The anterior curvature of the sacrum is a relatively smooth arc. If a fracture is present, it does not create a large enough change in the sacral curvature to be considred present.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Normal sacral curvature. The angle of sacral curvature, when viewed laterally, of normal individuals may appear to be similar to those with an "elbow". However, there is no break or sharp change in the angle on the anterior surface of the sacrum. (ID# 2386)

scores.title: present
scores.description: The normal superior to inferior curve of the sacrum must be interrupted by a distinct break (a sharp change in angle) of approximately 90-100 degrees. The angle often results from a readily visible antemortem fracture somewher eon or between the second and fourth sacral segment (S2-S4). The healed fracture, with ot without obvious remodeling, results in a change in the typically continuous contour of the ventral surface.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Anterior (specimen number removed from image) view. The angle in sacral curvature occurs between S2 and S3. (ID# 1791)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Lateral view. The angle in sacral curvature occurs between S2 and S3. (ID# 1791)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Anterior (specimen number removed from image) view of sacral elbow. The change in curvature occurs on S3. (ID# 2660)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Lateral view of sacral elbow. The change in curvature occurs on S3. (ID# 2660)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Lateral view of sacral elbow. The change in sacral curvature occurs between S3 and S4. An abrupt change in sacral curvature is the critical feature for the trait to be scored as present. Image reversed. (ID# 1670)

Lateral views of normal sacral curvature (a) and two sacral elbows (b,c). The angle created by an elbow in the sacral curvature is typically between approximately 90-110 degrees when viewed laterally.

traits.title: Cervical vertebral lipping
traits.location: The anterior portions of the superior and inferior edges of cervical vertebrae three through seven, and in all thoracic and lumbar vertebrae.
notes: Vertebae fused through lipping or candlewax should be scored as lipped.
Congenitally fused vertebrae, particularly common in the cervical spine, should not be scored.
It is not unusual for vertebral margins to appear highly irregular and porous, but has an insufficient amount of lipping to be scored as present. This is particularly common for cervical vertebrae.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: (a) Lipping extends outward from the original edge by < 5mm. (b) The original margin of the epiphyseal ring has been estimated (dotted line) and the lipping (solid line) is measured from this estimated edge. (ID# 2529)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The lipping on this lumbar vertebra extends outward from the estimated original edge by < 5mm. (ID# 1438)

scores.title: present (>=3mm)
scores.description: Lipping is present if it extends anteriorly, cranially, or caudally from the margin >= 3mm for cervical or >= 5mm for thoracic and lumbar vertebrae. Lipping is measured from the original vertebral margin to the furthest extent of the osteophyte (outward, upward, or downward from the vertebral body), not the distance along the margin.

images.title: Lipped (>= 5mm)
images.caption: Superior view of lumbar vertebra. Specimen number removed from image. (ID# 2141)

images.title: Lipped (>= 3mm)
images.caption: Inferior view of a cervical vertebra with lipping that extends >= 3mm. Scoring thresholds were selected to be easily evaluated by eye in most cases, although verification with a ruler is recommended. (ID# 2649)

images.title: Lipped (>= 5mm)
images.caption: Thoracic lipping that is also candlewax. (ID# 2689)

images.title: Lipped (>= 3mm)
images.caption: Fusion of two cervical vertebrae through candlewax. Fusion in this manner is sufficient to be scored as lipped, however, the inferior border of the lower of the two fused vertebrae has sufficient lipping to be independently scored as lipped. (ID# 2629)

traits.title: Cervical vertebral candlewax
traits.location: Superior edges, inferior edges and anterior surfaces of the vertebral bodies of cervical three through seven, and all thoracic and lumbar vertebra.
notes: Fusion of vertebral elements is not necessary for candlewax to be present.

As compared to osteophytes, which originate from the margins of the vertebrae, the smooth, shiny sclerotic bone characteristic of candlewax is typically present on the anterior surfaces fo the vertebrae, as well as flowing over and across the joint margins.

scores.title: present
scores.description: Candlewax is a distinctive form of bony growth typically associated with advanced osteoarthritis and Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH). The hard and smooth (sclerotic) bone looks like hardened candlwax that has flowed down the vertebral bodies and acorss the joints between vertebrae. Candlewax expands at the joints of the vertebrae, creating swelings in the bony flow. If candlewax is visible on one or more of the vertebral edges, then the trait is scored as present.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Minor, unfused candlewax. The candlewax originates on the body of the vertebrae, spans the joint space, and has a different texture than the surrounding bone. (ID# 1978)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Anterior view of unfused candlewax present only on the left inferior edges. The candlewax originates on the body of the vertebra, spans the joint space, and has a sclerotic appearance. (ID# 2016)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Lateral-oblique view of unfused candlewax present only on the left inferior edges. The candlewax originates on the body of the vertebra, spans the joint space, and has a sclerotic appearance. (ID# 2016)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Candlewax of adjacent vertebrae spans the joint space and forms touching facets, but is not fused. It is different in both color and texture than the surrounding bone. (ID# 2689)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Lateral view of candlewax-fused vertebrae. (ID# 2615)

images.title: Present

traits.title: Cervical Vertebral DISH
traits.location: Superior edges, inferior edges and anterior surfaces of vertebral bodies.
notes: If four or more vertebrae are not present (e.g. only two bones are present), the presence of DISH cannot be scored.

scores.title: absent (<4 vertebrae)
scores.description: Candlewax is absent or does not span three or more joints.

scores.title: present (>= 4 vertebrae)
scores.description:
Candlewax is hard and smooth surfaced (sclerotic) bone that looks like wax flowing down and across the joints between the vetebrae. Usually the candlewax expands at the joints of vertebrae where it spans the normal joint space, which results in swellings in the bony flow.

If candlewax is present on four or more adjacent vertebrae (crossing three or more joints) in the same orientation (on the same side of the vertebrae), then DISH is scored as present. When present, the type of vertebrae fused should be noted (C - Cervical; T - Thoracic; L - Lumbar).

images.title: Present
images.caption: Unfused candlewax is present and spans more than three contiguous joints (four vertebrae). (ID# 2689)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Anterior view of fused candlewax that spans more than three contiguous joints (four vertebrae) on the same side. DISH in the thoracic spine most commonly occurs on the right side, but can occur anywhere on the vertebral bodies. (ID# 2615)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Lateral view of fused candlewax that spans more than three contiguous joints (four vertebrae) on the same side. DISH in the thoracic spine most commonly occurs on the right side, but can occur anywhere on the vertebral bodies. (ID# 2615)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Candlewax is present on both the anterior and right lateral surfaces of more than four vertebrae. (ID# 1876)

traits.title: Rib 1 fusion (left)
traits.location: The manubrium, first rib, and costal space between them.
notes: Be sure to look carefully for bony connections between the first rib and manubrium that may have been broken postmortem.
When the first costal cartilage has been preserved, look closely to determine whether the first rib has truly fused to the manubrium or is only held in place by dried or partially ossified cartilage.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Anterior view. The first ribs are attached bilaterally to the manubrium by dried cartilage. Isolated ossifications are present in the space between the first rib and the manubrium, but no bony bridges connect them. (ID# 2449)

scores.title: fused
scores.description: The first rib is connected to the manubrium by at least one bony bridge on either or both sides.

traits.title: Sternum central dorsal ridge
traits.location: The dorsal (posterior) surface of the completely fused adult sternal body, excluding the manubrium and xiphoid process.
notes: A line of small, narrow, linearly oriented spicules that does not form a continuous ridge is insufficient to be scored as present.

A central ridge can be present in isolation or with similar lines or ridges that occur on the lateral borders of the sternal body. These laterally located lines can exist unilaterally, and should not be confused with the central dorsal ridge along the midline.
The feature cannot be scored if there has been thoracic surgery that involved cuting the sternum superiorly to inferiorly.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: No central ridge is present. Poorly expressed lateral ridges are present inferiorly, but only ridges located in the center of the dorsal sternum are scored. (ID# 2303)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: This is a slightly rounded, raised mound along the midline, but no substantial addition of bone. Specimen number removed from image. (ID# 1808)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: (a) Borderline case. A central line of narrow, linear spicules is present that are not 1.5mm wide. (b) It is common to have a raised area with rounded borders 10 to 20mm long in the superior portion of the sternal body that should not be confused with a central ridge. (ID#2486)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Borderline case. The central dorsal ridge is present but is not at least 15mm in length. Lateral ridges are also present, but are not scored as part of this trait. (ID# 2013)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: A single lateral ridge is present on the left side, but no central ossification is present. (ID# 2659)

scores.title: present
scores.description:
A single, central ridge runs superiorly to interfiorly along the midline of the dorsal sternal surface. It must be 15mm long and 1.5mm wide at least at one point.

The ridge is an addition of bone on the sternal surface with sharp borders. It can be seen and felt.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Posterior view. The central ridge is an addition of bone onto the surface that is at least 1.5mm wide and 15mm long with well-defined, sharp edges. (ID# 1940)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Lateral-oblique view. The central ridge is an addition of bone onto the surface that is at least 1.5mm wide and 15mm long with well-defined, sharp edges. (ID# 1940)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Posterior (a) and lateral-oblique (b) views of an unusually wide central dorsal ridge. Specimen numbers removed from images. (ID# 2004)

images.title: Present
images.caption: A central dorsal ridge is present, along with poorly defined lateral ridges. (ID# 2401)

images.title: Present
images.caption: A central dorsal ridge is present, along with poorly defined lateral ridges. (ID# 2435)

images.title: Present
images.caption: A short (>= 15mm) segment of ossification is located in the superior part of the sternal body. The well-defined edges indicate that this is a central ridge and not the raised mound that often occurs in people of all ages. (ID# 2547)

traits.title: Rib 2 sternal end rim profiles
traits.location: The sternal end of rib two (R2), specifically the oval margin of each rib end where bone meets costal cartilage.
notes: Occasionally tube-like ossifications encircle the entire sternal end of a rib, but do not form jagged (or claw-like) protrustions. These ossifications of cartilage are also classified as irregular.

scores.title: regular
scores.description: The end of the rib is straight or scalloped, but not lipped.

images.title: Regular
images.caption: Regular rim with well-defined scallops. (ID# 1804)

images.title: Regular
images.caption: The edges are thick and rounded. (ID# 2464)

images.title: Regular
images.caption: The edges are rounded and the bone is dense with a slightly scalloped appearance. (ID# 2454)

scores.title: irregular
scores.description: The margins of the sternal end are typically thin and even a small amount of bone growth results in an irregular appearance. In many cases, additional irregular ossifications project beyond the original borders of the rim resulting in a ragged or claw-like appearance.

images.title: Irregular
images.caption: The majority of the edge is straight with slight areas of irregularity. (ID# 2303)

images.title: Irregular

images.title: Irregular

images.caption: Tube-like ossification. (ID# 1485)

images.title: Irregular
images.caption: Ossification that takes the form of a cylinder or tube. Arrow indicates the original end of the rib. (ID# 1952)

traits.title: Rib 2 ossification pattern
traits.location: The sternal end of rib two (R2), specifically the oval margin of each rib end where the bone meets costal cartilage.
notes: Occasionally tube-like ossifications encircle the entire sternal end of a rib, but do not form jagged (or claw-like) protrustions. These ossifications of cartilage are also classified as irregular.
It is possible to have a cone on a rib with a regular rim.
Ribs with claws must, by definition, be scored as irregular.
A single individual might have claws, cones, and both. That is, ribs with only claws, only cones, and both claws and cones.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Irregular rim with no claw. At least 5mm of ossification must extend beyond the original border of the rib for a claw to be present. (ID# 2303)

scores.title: cone
scores.description: Cones appear to originate from the central portion of the costal face and extend at least 5mm or more, typically as gradually tapering, hollow bony growths.

images.title: Cone
images.caption: Ossification originating from the central portion of the sternal end. (ID# 1940)

scores.title: claw
scores.description: Claws originate from the perimeter of the sternal end and have a jagged appearance, formed by irregular ossifications >= 5mm in length. Hollow, cylinder or tube-like ossifications that encircle the sternal end should be scored as claws.

images.title: Claw

images.title: Claw
images.caption: Cylindrical ossification that originates from the borders of the sternal end, along with a more typical claw-like projection (left side). (ID# 1808)

images.title: Claw
images.caption: Partial tube-like ossification originating from the lateral margins of the rib. (ID# 2005)

scores.title: both
scores.description: Both claws and cones are present.

images.title: Both
images.caption: Unusually long claw, bordering an even longer, tapering cone. (ID# 2327)

traits.title: Rib 2 shingle ribs
traits.location: The ventral third of the second rib (R2).
notes: The overwhelming majority of individuals have normal ribs. Shingle ribs are only present in clear-cut cases of thinning.
Shingle ribs are defined by their overall cross-sectional shape, not cortical thickness. However, all shingle ribs have extremely thin cortices.

scores.title: normal
scores.description: The bone has a thick and robust appearance. The cross sections of ribs form an elongated oval with a rounded superior border and, typically, a sharp inferior border adjacent to the costal groove.

images.title: Normal (a) and shingle (b)
images.caption: Interior-oblique view of an (a) normal and (b) shingle rib (image reversed). (a:ID# 2602, b:ID# 2509)

images.title: Normal
images.caption: Inferior view of a normal rib. (ID# 2602)

images.title: Normal (a) and shingle (b)
images.caption: Comparison of a normal rib and a shingle rib. The sides of the shingle rib are flat and parallel to one another. (a: unknown, b:ID# 1668)

images.title: Normal (a) and shingle (b)
images.caption: It is not uncommon for an individual to have both normal (a) and shingle ribs (b). (ID# 2678)

scores.title: shingle
scores.description: Shingle ribs are quite narrow in cross section, and taper to a sharp margin both superiorly and inferiorly. The cortices are thin, especially noticeable in broken bones, and trabeculae are sparse. In cross section, the exterior and interior sides of the ribs parallel to one another, instead of the usual oval shape found in most adults. If present, the flattening generally occurs in the most distal (costal) thirds of the ribs, but can extend to as much as the distal two-thirds of the rib body.

images.title: Shingle
images.caption: Inferior view of a shingle rib (image reversed). (ID# 2509)

images.title: Normal (a) and shingle (b)
images.caption: Comparison of a normal rib and a shingle rib. The sides of the shingle rib are flat and parallel to one another. (a: unknown, b:ID# 1668)

images.title: Normal (a) and shingle (b)
images.caption: It is not uncommon for an individual to have both normal (a) and shingle ribs (b). (ID# 2678)

images.title: Shingle
images.caption: Both edges of the rib are extremely sharp (superior edge can be seen in the photograph). The distal third of the rib body is thin and flat (b), while the rest retains a more normal contour (a). (ID# 2678)

traits.title: Clavicle medial epiphysis fusion (left)
traits.location: Edges and surface of the medial end of the clavicle.
notes: When the medial clavicle exhibits a deep conical divot, which can be unilateral or bilateral, epiphyseal fusion is not scored.
When a shallow or partial divot is present, the medial epiphysis can be scored, but a note should be made regarding the presence of the feature.

scores.title: not fused (NF)
scores.description: A ridged surface where there is no evidence of a fusing epiphysis.

scores.title: partially fused (PF)
scores.description: A low, smooth epiphysis covers part of the original ridge surface. It can be centrally or peripherally located. There is a distinct space between the edge of the fusing epiphysis and the original bone surface.

images.title: Partially fused
images.caption: Image reversed. (ID# 2015)

scores.title: remnant line (RL)
scores.description: There is a narrow and shallow groove where the epiphysis joins the rest of the bone. The line is a shallow, groove at least 5mm long with a fused bottom.

scores.title: fully fused (FF)
scores.description: There is no evidence of where the epiphysis fused to the bone.

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: Medial (a) an oblique (b) views of a deep conical divot. The clavicle should not be scored when this feature is present. (ID# 2476)

traits.title: Clavicle medial epiphysis gravel (left)
traits.location: Surface of the medical end of the clavicle
notes: A shallow divot can change the texture of the medial epiphysis. Gravel typically exists on a roughened surface.
The feature cannot be scored when a deep conical divot is present.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The surface of the medial clavicle is smooth, with or without microporosity, or the irregular bone growth does not cover 5mm or more of the surface. IF the epiphysis is not present (not fused or partially fused), then the trait is scored as absent.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The bumpy, but regular, unfused epiphyseal surface should not be confused with the irregular gravel. (ID# 2405)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The epiphysis is only partially fused, so gravel is absent. (ID# 1841)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Left clavicle with a common shape variant (shallow concical divot) that often results in a corrugated texture. This texture is regular and the bone is smooth. It should not be mistaken for irregular bone growth added to the surface that is classified as "gravel". (ID# 1445)

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: When a deep conical divot is present, the feature cannot be scored. (ID# 2476)

scores.title: present
scores.description: A layer of irregular bone that is >= 5mm in its longest dimension is present on top of the original clavicular surface. In many cases, the texture resembles a gravel road's surface.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Both macroporosity and an irregular addition of bone longer than 5mm in length are present. (ID# 1526)

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: When a deep conical divot is present, the feature cannot be scored. (ID# 2476)

traits.title: Clavicle medial macroporosity (left)
traits.location: Surface of the medical end of the clavicle
notes: Macropores in the central part of a clavicle with a shallow or deep conical divot are not scored.

Macropores can occur on the original surface of the bone or in (or around) areas of lumpy, irregular bown deposited on its surface. If present, the pores should be scored regardless of other textural changes.

Developmental defects resembling macropores can occur on the medial clavicular surface. These defects have rounded margins and smooth walls with fused bottoms that do not expose the underlying trabecular bone. These defects are similar to those sometimes found on other articulation surfaces, such as the iliac auricular surface.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The medial end is smooth, has only microporosity, or has fewer than three macropores.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The epiphysis is unfused, so porosity is absent. (ID# 2405)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The epiphysis is only partially fused, so porosity is absent. (ID# 1841)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Several surface defects are present in the central portion of a shallow concical divot. As opposed to true macropores, these defects occur on a dense surface and have rounded borders. (ID# 2581)

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: When a deep conical divot is present, the feature cannot be scored. If the entire surface is visible, any macroporosity in the depths of the divot is not scored. (ID# 2476)

scores.title: macroposity (>=3)
scores.description: The surface has 3 or more pores that are 1mm or larger. The feature should be scored as many when more than 75% of the medial surface is macroporous.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Macroporosity is present within irregular bone growth. This is scored in the same way as macropores that occur directly on the subchonral surface. (ID# 2133)

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: When a deep conical divot is present, the feature cannot be scored. If the entire surface is visible, any macroporosity in the depths of the divot is not scored. (ID# 2476)

scores.title: macroposity (>=75%)
scores.description: The surface has 3 or more pores that are 1mm or larger. The feature should be scored as many when more than 75% of the medial surface is macroporous.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Macroporosity is present within irregular bone growth. This is scored in the same way as macropores that occur directly on the subchonral surface. (ID# 2133)

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: When a deep conical divot is present, the feature cannot be scored. If the entire surface is visible, any macroporosity in the depths of the divot is not scored. (ID# 2476)

traits.title: Clavicle lateral macroporosity (left)
traits.location: The lateral articulation surface where the clavicle meets the acromion process of the scapula.
notes: Macropores must be on the normally smooth articulation surface to be scored. Macropores only on the edge of the bone should not be scored.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The articular surface is smooth, has only microporosity, or has fewer than three large pores.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The surface has some microporosity, but no macropores are present. (ID# 1445)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Several large micropores are present, but are insufficient to qualify as macropores. (ID# 2728)

scores.title: macroposity (>=3 holes)
scores.description: The articulation surface has 3 or more pores that are 1mm or larger.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Macropores are present within additional irregular bony growth. (ID# 2133)

traits.title: Scapula glenoid foss lipping (left)
traits.generic_title: Scap glen fossa elevated shp & lip
traits.location: The margins of the articulation surface of the glenoid foss.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The entire glenoid fossa has smooth rounded edges that flow without interruption from the articular surface to the external surface of the joint and beyond.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The epiphyses are unfused, thus no lipping can be present. (ID# 1125)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The borders of the entire glenoid fossa are rounded. No raised edges or lipping are present. (ID# 1780)

scores.title: present (<1/2)
scores.description:
Lipping refers to the irregular bony growths much like what occurs at the margins of other synovial joints. The lipping can either extend laterally [towards the humerus] or perpendicularly outwards from the joint. Lipping is almost always easy to see, but early lipping may take the form of a narrow, but sharp and elevated rim.

In the <1/2 category, some sharp elevation or irregular bony lipping is present but covers less than one-half of the circumference of glenoid fossa.

scores.title: present (>=1/2)
scores.description:
Lipping refers to the irregular bony growths much like what occurs at the margins of other synovial joints. The lipping can either extend laterally [towards the humerus] or perpendicularly outwards from the joint. Lipping is almost always easy to see, but early lipping may take the form of a narrow, but sharp and elevated rim.

In the >= 1/2 category, a sharp, elevated margin or bony lipping is present around at least one-half of the circumference of the margin.

images.title: Present (>= 1/2)
images.caption: Minor lipping is present around the entire glenoid fossa. (ID# 2659)

images.title: Present (>= 1/2)
images.caption: Lipping is present around almost all of the glenoid fossa. (ID# 1411)

images.title: Present (>= 1/2)
images.caption: The entire glenoid fossa is eburnated and expanded with irregular lipping. (ID# 1472)

traits.title: Clavicle medial epiphysis fusion (right)
traits.location: Edges and surface of the medial end of the clavicle.
notes: When the medial clavicle exhibits a deep conical divot, which can be unilateral or bilateral, epiphyseal fusion is not scored.
When a shallow or partial divot is present, the medial epiphysis can be scored, but a note should be made regarding the presence of the feature.

scores.title: not fused (NF)
scores.description: A ridged surface where there is no evidence of a fusing epiphysis.

scores.title: partially fused (PF)
scores.description: A low, smooth epiphysis covers part of the original ridge surface. It can be centrally or peripherally located. There is a distinct space between the edge of the fusing epiphysis and the original bone surface.

images.title: Partially fused
images.caption: Image reversed. (ID# 2015)

scores.title: remnant line (RL)
scores.description: There is a narrow and shallow groove where the epiphysis joins the rest of the bone. The line is a shallow, groove at least 5mm long with a fused bottom.

scores.title: fully fused (FF)
scores.description: There is no evidence of where the epiphysis fused to the bone.

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: Medial (a) an oblique (b) views of a deep conical divot. The clavicle should not be scored when this feature is present. (ID# 2476)

traits.title: Clavicle medial epiphysis gravel (right)
traits.location: Surface of the medical end of the clavicle
notes: A shallow divot can change the texture of the medial epiphysis. Gravel typically exists on a roughened surface.
The feature cannot be scored when a deep conical divot is present.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The surface of the medial clavicle is smooth, with or without microporosity, or the irregular bone growth does not cover 5mm or more of the surface. IF the epiphysis is not present (not fused or partially fused), then the trait is scored as absent.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The bumpy, but regular, unfused epiphyseal surface should not be confused with the irregular gravel. (ID# 2405)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The epiphysis is only partially fused, so gravel is absent. (ID# 1841)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Right clavicle with a common shape variant (shallow concical divot) that often results in a corrugated texture. This texture is regular and the bone is smooth. It should not be mistaken for irregular bone growth added to the surface that is classified as "gravel". (ID# 1445)

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: When a deep conical divot is present, the feature cannot be scored. (ID# 2476)

scores.title: present
scores.description: A layer of irregular bone that is >= 5mm in its longest dimension is present on top of the original clavicular surface. In many cases, the texture resembles a gravel road's surface.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Both macroporosity and an irregular addition of bone longer than 5mm in length are present. (ID# 1526)

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: When a deep conical divot is present, the feature cannot be scored. (ID# 2476)

traits.title: Clavicle medial macroporosity (right)
traits.location: Surface of the medical end of the clavicle
notes: Macropores in the central part of a clavicle with a shallow or deep conical divot are not scored.

Macropores can occur on the original surface of the bone or in (or around) areas of lumpy, irregular bown deposited on its surface. If present, the pores should be scored regardless of other textural changes.

Developmental defects resembling macropores can occur on the medial clavicular surface. These defects have rounded margins and smooth walls with fused bottoms that do not expose the underlying trabecular bone. These defects are similar to those sometimes found on other articulation surfaces, such as the iliac auricular surface.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The medial end is smooth, has only microporosity, or has fewer than three macropores.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The epiphysis is unfused, so porosity is absent. (ID# 2405)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The epiphysis is only partially fused, so porosity is absent. (ID# 1841)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Several surface defects are present in the central portion of a shallow concical divot. As opposed to true macropores, these defects occur on a dense surface and have rounded borders. (ID# 2581)

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: When a deep conical divot is present, the feature cannot be scored. If the entire surface is visible, any macroporosity in the depths of the divot is not scored. (ID# 2476)

scores.title: macroposity (>=3)
scores.description: The surface has 3 or more pores that are 1mm or larger. The feature should be scored as many when more than 75% of the medial surface is macroporous.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Macroporosity is present within irregular bone growth. This is scored in the same way as macropores that occur directly on the subchonral surface. (ID# 2133)

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: When a deep conical divot is present, the feature cannot be scored. If the entire surface is visible, any macroporosity in the depths of the divot is not scored. (ID# 2476)

scores.title: macroposity (>=75%)
scores.description: The surface has 3 or more pores that are 1mm or larger. The feature should be scored as many when more than 75% of the medial surface is macroporous.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Macroporosity is present within irregular bone growth. This is scored in the same way as macropores that occur directly on the subchonral surface. (ID# 2133)

images.title: Not scorable
images.caption: When a deep conical divot is present, the feature cannot be scored. If the entire surface is visible, any macroporosity in the depths of the divot is not scored. (ID# 2476)

notes: Macropores must be on the normally smooth articulation surface to be scored. Macropores only on the edge of the bone should not be scored.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The articular surface is smooth, has only microporosity, or has fewer than three large pores.

images.title: Absent

scores.title: macroposity (>=3 holes)
scores.description: The articulation surface has 3 or more pores that are 1mm or larger.

images.title: Present

traits.title: Humerus weight
traits.location: The entire humerus
notes: This trait should be recorded or, at least, mentally noted when the bones are first picked up, usually as the box is being unpacked. Handling bones for some time before scoring can result in skewed perceptions of relative bone weight.
In rare cases bone weight is asymmetric. When this occurs, record both sides, and make a note on the data form.

scores.title: normal
scores.description: The weight of the humerus falls within what is expected for an individual of that size. Bones that are borderline, or only slightly lighter than normal, should be scored as normal. This observation is subjective, so err on the side of classifying the bone as normal.

scores.title: light
scores.description: The bone must be noticeably lighter than expected, but otherwise normal in appearance. A light humerus typically feels like an extremely light, hollow, cortical bone shell.

traits.title: Humerus lesser tubercle bumps (left)
traits.location: Anterior surface of the lesser tubercle of the humerus.
notes: Irregular pitting sometimes covers part or all of the anterior surface of the lesser tubercle. If the face is entirely covered in pitting, this feature cannot be scored. If some pitting is present, it should be ignored, and the bone is scored based on the criteria described above.
This trait cannot be scored when eburnation and lipping of the humeral head has obliterated much or all of the lesser tubercle.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The anterior surface of the lesser tuberle is smooth, or < 1/3 of its surface is covered in bumps.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The anterior surface of the lesser tubercle is slightly granular near the margin, but the bone surface is completely smooth. Image reversed. (ID# 1143)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The anterior surface of the lesser tubercle is completely smooth. (ID# 2438)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The anterior surface of the tubercle has several linear elevations, but no irregular bone growth (bumps) are present that appear as if they sit on top of the surface. (ID# 2359)

scores.title: present (>=1/3)
scores.description: Bumps range from low, rounded elevattions just above the surface of the bone to large, irregular exostoses of several millimeters or more. Bumps must cover >= 1/3 of the anterior surface of the tubercle to be present.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Just over one-third of the surface is covered by exostoses. The pits are ignored. Image reversed. (ID# 2328)

images.title: Present

traits.title: Trapezium lipping (left)
traits.location: The circumference of the saddle-shaped articulation surface for the first metacarpal.
notes: When the trapezium has fused to MC1 as a result of arthritic bony lipping (not trauma), the feature should be sored as present.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: No lipping, or < 2mm of lipping, project outward from at least two points along the joint margin. The key feature is the absence of marked lipping. Sometimes bones marked as absent can display some eburnation, but there is little marginal lipping and the articulation surface retains its overall saddle-shaped appearance.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Only slight lipping is present around the left and right articular surfaces. (ID# 1906)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Approximately 1mm of extra bone growth is present around the entire articular surface. (ID# 1937)

scores.title: present (>= 2mm)
scores.description: At least 2mm of lipping extends outward from at least two points along the margin of the saddle-shaped articulation surface. In advanced cases, the articulation surface becomes flat to irregular, lipping at the margin is extensive, and the bone no longer retains the overall shape of a trapezium.

images.title: Present
images.caption: More than 2mm of lipping extends from at least two points on the left bone. (ID# 2237)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Bilateral lipped surfaces that also have extensive eburnation. (ID# 1919)

traits.title: Radius tuberosity medial crest (right)

scores.title: absent

images.title: Absent

images.title: Absent

scores.title: present (>= 1mm high and 10mm long)
scores.description: A distinctive, narrow, and high crest of bone is present where the tendon inserts. This bony growth extends above the tuberosity surface by >= 1mm for >= 10mm in a proximal to distal direction. This ridge can have the appearance of a wave with its crest inclined over the normally smooth part of the tubercle where a bursa is located in life.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Anterior (R1) and oblique (R2) views of the same right radius. The medial tuberosity has the distinctibve wave-shaped crest. (ID# 1823)

images.title: Present

traits.title: Femur fovea margin lipping (left)
traits.location: The margin of the femoral fovea where the ligamentum teres attaches (ligamentum capitis femoris).
notes: In some cases, lipping around the fovea merges with an adjacent area of roughening on the femoral head.
Rarely the fovea is small and appears filled in with bone with no margin clearly separable from the interior. These atypical femora are not scored for this trait.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The edge of the fovea is smooth or, more typically, has a rounded or sharp margin.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The margins of the fovea are slightly raised, but are smooth and rounded. (ID# 2727)

images.title: Absent
images.caption: The fovea has a raised and sharp, but regular, margin. For lipping to be present, the bone growth around the fovea must be irregular. (ID# 1143)

images.title: Unscorable
images.caption: The fovea cannot be scored because more than 10mm of the fovea is damaged. It is not possible to tell how much lipping was originally present. (ID# 2733)

scores.title: lipped (>= 10mm)
scores.description:
Irregular bony growths extends continuously for >= 10mm around the fovea margin.

This irregular lipping can be as much as 2-4mm wide, which looks like a flat plateau extending beyond the edge of the fovea.

images.title: Lipped
images.caption: The entire fovea is slightly irregular with some postmortem damage present on the inferior border. (ID# 2000)

images.title: Lipped
images.caption: The entire fovea has a thick, irregular rim. (ID# 1552)

images.title: Unscorable
images.caption: The fovea cannot be scored because more than 10mm of the fovea is damaged. It is not possible to tell how much lipping was originally present. (ID# 2733)

traits.title: Femur head surface extra bone (left)
traits.location: The femoral head, excluding the area in immediate proximity to the articulation margin with the femoral neck (edge of the femoral head).
notes: Sometimes lipping of the fovea margin and the rough femoral surface area join one another.

Often the rough area lies immediately alongside the fovea, and it may join the lipping that defines the fovea's edge. The bone deposits, however, can be islands of rough-looking bone separated by as much as a centimeter or more from the fovea. In the intervening area, the original sooth subchondral bone is visible.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The normally smooth articulation surface of the femoral head is either smooth, or has < 5mm of a bone deposit. If pitting (removal of bone from the surface) is present, it should be ignored.

images.title: Absent

images.title: Absent

images.title: Absent

scores.title: extra bone (5-9.9mm)

scores.title: extra bone (>=10mm)
scores.description: Extra bone measuring >= 5mm in its longest dimension is present on the articulation surface.

traits.title: Femur greater trochanter roughening (left)
traits.location: The lateral surface and lateral-inferior edge of the greater trochanter.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The bone is smooth, or only a small area (< 10x20mm triangle) is rough.

scores.title: rough (triangle)
scores.description: A 10x20mm triangle of slightly to extensively rough bone is present on the surface.

scores.title: rough (rectangle)
scores.description: A 10x20mm rectangle of bone is slightly to extensively roughened by the addition of flat to irregular bone growth on top of the trochanter's original smooth surface. No overhand of sufficient size is present.

scores.title: overhang
scores.description: Irregular bony growth extends >= 1mm distally from the original surface of the bone for >= 10mm horizontally along the greater trochanter's inferior margin. When viewed anteriorly or posteriorly, there is a gap between the femur shaft and the extra bone growth (i.e. an overhang).

images.title: Overhang
images.caption: Lateral (a) view of an overhang. The roughened bone on the posterior view (a) is characteristic of the type of deposits scored in both roughened categories. (ID# 1831)

images.title: Overhang
images.caption: Posterior (b) view of an overhang. The roughened bone on the posterior view (a) is characteristic of the type of deposits scored in both roughened categories. (ID# 1831)

traits.location: Depths of the trochanteric fossa where the obturator externus inserts.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The area is smooth with little or no evidence of generally sharp exostoses. A single exostosis is considered absent.

scores.title: present
scores.description: At least two exostoses are clearly visible in the depths of the fossa. Occasionally the exostoses will merge into a single large area with multiple peaks, and is also scored as present.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Extostoses located (L) within and (R) slightly superior to the depths of teh trochanteric fossa. (ID# 2328)

images.title: Present
images.caption: The trochanteric fossa (circled) and medial trochanteric fossa exostoses are present. (ID# 1800)

images.title: Present

traits.title: Femur trochanteric medial exostoses (left)
traits.location: Area immediately proximal to the trochanteric fossa on the medial side of the proximal end of the greater trochanter where obturator internus and gemelli insert.
notes: The exostoses generally form a distinctly rough patch of bone that is separate from the similar patch of roughened bone deep within the trochanteric fossa. The two areas are occasionally confluent.
Occasionally the exostoses take the form a rough raised rim surrounding a small oval tendon insertion.

In some individuals, this area has low raised, but regular, ridges that do not extend off the surface of the bone. In the absence of raised, distinct exostoses, the feature should be scored as absent.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The area is smooth or has, at most, a single exostosis.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Low rounded linear elevations that are not irregular additions of bone. (ID# 2486)

scores.title: present
scores.description: A patch of >= 2 exostoses, similar to those seen in the trochanteric fossa, are present.

images.title: Present

images.title: Present

traits.title: Fibula wings (left)
traits.location: The lateral surface and anterior edge of the lateral malleolus where the anterior talofibular and anterior tibiofibular ligaments attach.
notes: The most important feature is the amount of projection beyond the fibula's anterior margin. The other aspects of the feature, described above, are included in the definition because they often are the most apparent characteristic when the bone is first handled.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The feature is entirely abset, or the bony growth does not extend 1mm anteriorly beyond the margin of the fibula for a full 3mm in a proximal to distal direction.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Lateral (a) and medial (b) surfaces of a left fibula. A few faint striations are present on the lateral surface, but there is no ossification beyond the anterior border. In (b), slight postmortem damage makes the anterior border slightly irregular. (ID# 2547)

scores.title: present
scores.description: There is a projection of bone >= 1mm beyond the anterior margin of the fibula for >= 3mm in length (i.e. at least a 1x3mm rectangle). The anterior margin of the projection is typically irregular and its surface has multiple striations paralleling the long axis of the feature. This extension of bone, which continues onto the lateral surface of the fibula, has a smooth, sclerotic appearance.

images.title: Present
images.caption: Views of the lateral (top) and medial (bottom) surfaces. On the lateral surface there is obvious sclerotic ossification. The extention and length of the ossification 9at least 1mm extension x 3mm length) can be most easily measured by looking at the medial surface. (ID# 2659)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Lateral surface of a left fibula. (ID# 2325)

images.title: Present
images.caption: Medial surface of a left fibula. Specimen number removed. (ID# 2325)

traits.title: Tibia light weight
traits.location: The entire tibia
notes: This trait should be recorded or, at least, mentally noted, when the bones are first picked up, usually when unpacking the skeleton's box. Handling bones for some time before scoring can result in skewed perceptions of relative bone weight.
In only rare cases will bone weight be asymmetric. When that occurs, record both sides and make a note on the data collection form.

scores.title: normal
scores.description: The bone weight falls within what one might expect for an individual of that size. Bones that are borderline, or only slightly lighter than normal, should be scored as normal. This observation is subjective, so err on the side of classifying the bone as normal.

scores.title: light
scores.description: The bone must be noticeably lighter than expected, but otherwise normal in appearance. A light tibia is often little more than a cortical bone shell.

traits.title: Calcaneus light weight
traits.location: The entire calcaneus
notes: This trait should be recorded or, at least, mentally noted, when the bones are first picked up, usually when unpacking the skeleton's box. Handling bones for some time before scoring can result in skewed perceptions of relative bone weight.
In only rare cases will bone weight be asymmetric. When that occurs, record both sides and make a note on the data collection form.

scores.title: normal
scores.description: The bone weight falls within what one might expect for an individual of that size. Bones that are borderline, or only slightly lighter than normal, should be scored as normal. This observation is subjective, so err on the side of classifying the bone as normal.

scores.title: light
scores.description: The bone must be noticeably lighter than expected. The cortical bone is often extremely fragile and paper-thin.

traits.title: Sacroiliac joint fusion (left)
traits.location: The sacroiliac joint.
notes: If the sacrum, innominate, or both show damage in the region of the sacroiliac joint, they should be examined closely to determine if a bony connection between the two was broken postmortem.

scores.title: normal
scores.description: If no bony union exists between the two elements, the trait is absent.

scores.title: fused
scores.description: The sacrum is fused to the ilium through bony ossifications in any location. The location of the fusion should be noted.

images.title: Present

images.title: Present

scores.title: superior-anterior (SA)
scores.description: The sacrum and ilium are fused via a bony connection in the region where the anterior sacroiliac ligament exists.

traits.title: Iliac crest fusion (left)
traits.location: The most superior part of the iliac blade anterior to, and including, the iliac tubercle.

scores.title: not fused (NF)
scores.description: The epiphysis is not present and the underlying epiphyseal surface is visible.

images.title: Not fused
images.caption: Anterior oblique view of an unfused iliac crest. (ID# 1125)

scores.title: partially fused (PF)
scores.description: The epiphysis is only partly joined to the blade of the ilium. The edges of the epiphysis are sharp and the botto of the groove between the epiphysis and iliac body is open. In many cases, the partially fused epiphysis is partly broken from the iliac blad.

images.title: Partially fused
images.caption: View of the external surface. The epiphysis is attached to the body of ilium, but the bottom of the groove between the bones is open (unfused). (ID# 1780)

images.title: Partially fused
images.caption: A fusing iliac crest viewed from the internal surface. The posterior half of the iliac crest is not fused, but is outside the scoring area. (ID# 2735)

images.title: Partially fused
images.caption: A fusing iliac crest viewed from the external surface. The posterior half of the iliac crest is not fused, but is outside the scoring area. Specimen number removed from image. (ID# 2735)

scores.title: remnant line (RL)
scores.description: The epiphysis is completely fused, but not fully integrated into the ilium. A long shallow but distinct channel, at least 10mm long, with a fused bottom is present.

scores.title: fully fused (FF)
scores.description: There is no evidence of where the epiphysis has fused.

traits.title: Iliac crest tuberculum ossification (left)
traits.location: The area of the iliac crest from the tuberculum (iliac tubercle) -- a rounded prominence on the ege of the iliac crest posterior to the anterior superior iliac spine -- to halfway to the anterior superior iliac spine.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: No ossification is present, or it does not meet the size requirements.

images.title: Absent
