images.title: Absent
images.caption: Superior view of slight ossifications that do not meet the length and extension requirements to be considered present. (ID# 1566)

scores.title: ossification
scores.description: Ossification occurs on the lateral edge of the iliac tuberculum where fascia attaches in life. It must extend outward from the original border of the iliac crest for >= 3mm for >= 10mm along the iliac crest.

images.title: Ossification
images.caption: A single ossification (at least 3x10mm) is present. (ID# 1442)

scores.title: double ossification
scores.description: Double ossification occurs when two (rarely more) distinguishable rows of ossification each extend away from the original border of the iliac crest for >= 3mm along >= 10mm of the crest.

images.title: Double Ossification
images.caption: Two layers of ossification (at least 3x10mm) are present. (ID# 1380)

traits.title: Iliac AIIS exostoses (left)
traits.location: Surface of the anterior inferior iliac spine.
notes: Small exostoses can give the bone a slightly roughened appearance. If < 25% of the surface of the AIIS shows original, smooth, unmodified bone, the feature should be considered present (exostoses).

scores.title: absent (<75%)
scores.description: The surface is smooth or, if exostoses are present, the roughened area covers < 75% of the surface.

scores.title: exostoses (>=75%)
scores.description: Numerous low rounded elevations of bone (exostoses) produce a rough surface that cover >= 75% of the anterior inferior iliac spin (AIIS).

traits.title: Acetabulum posterior margin lipping (left)
traits.location: The 30mm forming the posterior portion of the acetabulum's outer margin.
notes: When lipping is present, traces of the original edge of the joint are often still visible. The lipping extends outward from the original edge. Frequently the easiest way to visualize the lipping is when viewing the bone from the acetabular surface.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: The outer edge of the acetabulum is smooth and it can be either round or sharp. That is, in cross-section the rim is U- or V-shaped from the articulation (joint) surface to the outer of the bone.

scores.title: present (>=10mm)
scores.description: In the present category, noticeable and irregular bony lipping occurs along a continuous >= 10mm of the acetabulum's margin.

images.title: Present (>= 10mm)
images.caption: Image reversed. (ID# 2022)

images.title: Present (>= 10mm)
images.caption: Image reversed. (ID# 1380)

traits.title: Acetabulum posterior articular surface roughening (left)

notes: The bony growth is typically separated from the joint margin, and any lipping that might occur there, by a narrow strip of the original joint surface. However, there are oaccasions when the margin lipping and joint surface roughening are immediately adjacent to one other.

scores.title: absent

traits.title: Innominate light weight
traits.location: The entire innominate
notes: This trait should be recorded or, at least, mentally noted, when the bones are first picked up, usually when unpacking the skeleton's box. Handling bones for some time before scoring can result in skewed perceptions of relative bone weight.
In only rare cases will bone weight be asymmetric. When that occurs, record both sides and make a note on the data collection form.

scores.title: normal
scores.description: The bone weight falls within what one might expect for an individual of that size. Bones that are borderline, or only slightly lighter than normal, should be scored as normal. This observation is subjective, so err on the side of classifying the bone as normal.

scores.title: light
scores.description: The bone must be noticeably lighter than expected, but otherwise normal in appearance. In light innominates, the cortical bone is often extremely fragile and paper-thin.

traits.title: Inferior surface porosity (left)
traits.location: Most inferior 10m (in a superior to inferior direction) of the inferior demiface -- do not include any marginal lipping that extends beyond the original margin of the joint surface.

scores.title: smooth
scores.description: There is little or no porosity in the scored area.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Some microporosity is present on the inferior portion of the auricular surface, but it does not cover at least one-half of the area. (ID# 2737)

scores.title: porosity (microporosity or macroporosity >= 1/2 of the area)
scores.description: Microporosity, macroporosity, or a combination of the two, covers >= 1/2 of the scored area.

images.title: Porosity
images.caption: More than half of the inferior 10mm of the auricular surface is covered in micro- and macroporosity. The area formed by additional lipping beyond the original end of the joint (red line) is not scored. (ID# 1552)

images.title: Porosity
images.caption: A combination of micro- and macroporosity covers essentially the entire scoring area. (ID# 1786)
Scoring location for inferior surface porosity.

traits.title: Superior posterior iliac exostoses (left)
traits.location: Medial surface of the posterior ilium where the ventral sacroiliac ligament attaches; in some individuals the bone is distinctly raised in this area.
notes: Sometimes the exostosis can take the form of an elongated ridge up to 10mm long. If the ridge is a dominant feature of this part of the bone, the trait is scored as exostoses.

When there is an articulation facet between the ilium and the sacrum that obscures the scored area or, when the bones are fused, the trait is not scored. However, if a facet is present and exostoses are also distinctly visible then it can be scored as exostoses.

scores.title: smooth
scores.description: The area is almost entirely smooth with, at most, one isolated small exostoses present.

images.title: Smooth
images.caption: The roughened texture of the developing retro-auricular area in very young adults should not be confused with the ossifications that develop later in life. (ID# 1125)

scores.title: exostoses (rounded, pointed, jagged)
scores.description: More than one exostosis, (rounded, pointed, or jagged in appearance) is present.

images.title: Exostoses
images.caption: The scoring area (circled) has several small, low, rounded exostoses (arrows). (ID# 1143)

images.title: Exostoses
images.caption: Some postmortem damage is present int he scoring area, but exostoses are still identifiable. (ID# 1472)

images.title: Exostoses
images.caption: An articulation facet is present, but extra bony growth is present around the facet. (ID# 2363)
Scoring locations of the superior posterior iliac exostoses.

traits.title: Inferior posterior iliac exostoses (left)
traits.location: Medial surface of the posterior ilium where the interosseous sacroiliac ligament attaches; in some individuals, the bone is distinctly raised in this area.
notes: When there is an articulation facet between the ilium and the sacrum that obscures the scored area or when the bones are fused, the trait is not scored. However, if a facet is present and exostoses are also distinctly visible, then it can be scored as exostoses.

scores.title: smooth
scores.description: The area is almost entirely smooth with, at most, one isolated small exostoses present.

scores.title: exostoses (rounded, pointed, jagged)
scores.description: More than one exostosis, (rounded, pointed, or jagged in appearance) is present.

images.title: Exostoses
images.caption: Low rounded exostoses cover teh entire inferior scoring area. (ID# 2517)
Scoring locations of the inferior posterior iliac exostoses.

traits.title: Posterior exostoses (left)
traits.location:
The posterior iliac area lies between the superior and inferior posterior iliac exostoses (as defined above)
  • The area where the exostoses occur is on the medial side of the ilium bordered posteriorly by the iliac crest, anteriorly by the sacroiliac joint surface, superiorly by a slightly raised area often surmounted by bony exostoses (superior posterior iliac exostoses), and inferiorly by a similar area (interior posterior iliac exostoses).
  • Excluded is a 5-10mm wide area of bone immediately posterior to the auricular surface where no exostoses ever form).
notes: The ilium and sacrum can be fused in several places. If that occurs, the posterior exostoses are not observable.
The vast majority of individuals fall into the discontinuous exostoses category.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: There are no exostoses in the scored area. It is completely smooth.

scores.title: discontinuous exostoses
scores.description: There is at least one exostosis in the area, often many of tem, but thye do not collectively cover the entire area of interest. That is, the exostoses often look like islands in a sea of flat bone.

images.title: Discontinuous exostoses
images.caption: The area between the scoring areas for the superior and inferior exostoses is mostly smooth, dense bone, but several small bony growths are present on the surface. Box indicates the area enlarged in (b). (ID# 2359)

images.title: Discontinuous exostoses
images.caption: The area between the scoring areas for the superior and inferior exostoses is mostly smooth, dense bone, but several small bony growths are present on the surface. Box indicates the area enlarged in (b). (ID# 2359)

images.title: Discontinuous exostoses
images.caption: The majority of the area is smooth dense bone, but several small bony growths are present on the surface. Box indicates the area enlarged in (b). Several exostoses are indicated (arrows) as examples. Image reversed. (ID# 2363)

images.title: Discontinuous exostoses
images.caption: The majority of the area is smooth dense bone, but several small bony growths are present on the surface. Box indicates the area enlarged in (b). Several exostoses are indicated (arrows) as examples. Image reversed. (ID# 2363)

scores.title: continuous exostoses
scores.description:
The area between the places where superior and inferior posterior iliac exostoses form must be entirely covered with low, rounded or pointed exostoses. The low exostoses give the normally smooth iliac surface a rough appearance. The surface, completely covered by exostoses, often looks as if a layer of coarse sand was laid over it. Little, if any, of the original smooth bone surface is visible.

It is important to realize that a strip of bone immediately posterior to the articulation surface is rarely, if ever, the sit of exostoses. This area is excluded when scoring the bone.

images.title: Continuous exostoses
images.caption: Slightly oblique view of a surface entirely convered by low rounded exostoses. Essentially none of the original smooth bone surface is visible between the bony growths. (ID# 2517)

images.title: Continuous exostoses
images.caption: The entire surface is covered by exostoses, except for the smooth area just posterior to the border of the auricular surface that is excluded from the scoring area. (ID# 1369)
Scoring locations of the posterior exostoses.

traits.title: Inferior surface porosity (right)
traits.location: Most inferior 10m (in a superior to inferior direction) of the inferior demiface -- do not include any marginal lipping that extends beyond the original margin of the joint surface.

scores.title: smooth
scores.description: There is little or no porosity in the scored area.

images.title: Absent
images.caption: Some microporosity is present on the inferior portion of the auricular surface, but it does not cover at least one-half of the area. (ID# 2737)

scores.title: porosity (microporosity or macroporosity >= 1/2 of the area)
scores.description: Microporosity, macroporosity, or a combination of the two, covers >= 1/2 of the scored area.

images.title: Porosity
images.caption: More than half of the inferior 10mm of the auricular surface is covered in micro- and macroporosity. The area formed by additional lipping beyond the original end of the joint (red line) is not scored. (ID# 1552)

images.title: Porosity
images.caption: A combination of micro- and macroporosity covers essentially the entire scoring area. (ID# 1786)
Scoring location for inferior surface porosity.

traits.title: Superior posterior iliac exostoses (right)
traits.location: Medial surface of the posterior ilium where the ventral sacroiliac ligament attaches; in some individuals the bone is distinctly raised in this area.
notes: Sometimes the exostosis can take the form of an elongated ridge up to 10mm long. If the ridge is a dominant feature of this part of the bone, the trait is scored as exostoses.

When there is an articulation facet between the ilium and the sacrum that obscures the scored area or, when the bones are fused, the trait is not scored. However, if a facet is present and exostoses are also distinctly visible then it can be scored as exostoses.

scores.title: smooth
scores.description: The area is almost entirely smooth with, at most, one isolated small exostoses present.

images.title: Smooth
images.caption: The roughened texture of the developing retro-auricular area in very young adults should not be confused with the ossifications that develop later in life. (ID# 1125)

scores.title: exostoses (rounded, pointed, jagged)
scores.description: More than one exostosis, (rounded, pointed, or jagged in appearance) is present.

images.title: Exostoses
images.caption: The scoring area (circled) has several small, low, rounded exostoses (arrows). (ID# 1143)

images.title: Exostoses
images.caption: Some postmortem damage is present int he scoring area, but exostoses are still identifiable. (ID# 1472)

images.title: Exostoses
images.caption: An articulation facet is present, but extra bony growth is present around the facet. (ID# 2363)
Scoring locations of the superior posterior iliac exostoses.

traits.title: Inferior posterior iliac exostoses (right)
traits.location: Medial surface of the posterior ilium where the interosseous sacroiliac ligament attaches; in some individuals, the bone is distinctly raised in this area.
notes: When there is an articulation facet between the ilium and the sacrum that obscures the scored area or when the bones are fused, the trait is not scored. However, if a facet is present and exostoses are also distinctly visible, then it can be scored as exostoses.

scores.title: smooth
scores.description: The area is almost entirely smooth with, at most, one isolated small exostoses present.

scores.title: exostoses (rounded, pointed, jagged)
scores.description: More than one exostosis, (rounded, pointed, or jagged in appearance) is present.

images.title: Exostoses
images.caption: Low rounded exostoses cover teh entire inferior scoring area. (ID# 2517)
Scoring locations of the inferior posterior iliac exostoses.

traits.title: Posterior exostoses (right)
traits.location:
The posterior iliac area lies between the superior and inferior posterior iliac exostoses (as defined above)
  • The area where the exostoses occur is on the medial side of the ilium bordered posteriorly by the iliac crest, anteriorly by the sacroiliac joint surface, superiorly by a slightly raised area often surmounted by bony exostoses (superior posterior iliac exostoses), and inferiorly by a similar area (interior posterior iliac exostoses).
  • Excluded is a 5-10mm wide area of bone immediately posterior to the auricular surface where no exostoses ever form).
notes: The ilium and sacrum can be fused in several places. If that occurs, the posterior exostoses are not observable.
The vast majority of individuals fall into the discontinuous exostoses category.

scores.title: absent
scores.description: There are no exostoses in the scored area. It is completely smooth.

scores.title: discontinuous exostoses
scores.description: There is at least one exostosis in the area, often many of tem, but thye do not collectively cover the entire area of interest. That is, the exostoses often look like islands in a sea of flat bone.

images.title: Discontinuous exostoses
images.caption: The area between the scoring areas for the superior and inferior exostoses is mostly smooth, dense bone, but several small bony growths are present on the surface. Box indicates the area enlarged in (b). (ID# 2359)

images.title: Discontinuous exostoses
images.caption: The area between the scoring areas for the superior and inferior exostoses is mostly smooth, dense bone, but several small bony growths are present on the surface. Box indicates the area enlarged in (b). (ID# 2359)

images.caption: The majority of the area is smooth dense bone, but several small bony growths are present on the surface. Box indicates the area enlarged in (b). Several exostoses are indicated (arrows) as examples. Image reversed. (ID# 2363)

scores.title: continuous exostoses
scores.description:
The area between the places where superior and inferior posterior iliac exostoses form must be entirely covered with low, rounded or pointed exostoses. The low exostoses give the normally smooth iliac surface a rough appearance. The surface, completely covered by exostoses, often looks as if a layer of coarse sand was laid over it. Little, if any, of the original smooth bone surface is visible.

It is important to realize that a strip of bone immediately posterior to the articulation surface is rarely, if ever, the sit of exostoses. This area is excluded when scoring the bone.

images.title: Continuous exostoses
images.caption: Slightly oblique view of a surface entirely convered by low rounded exostoses. Essentially none of the original smooth bone surface is visible between the bony growths. (ID# 2517)

images.caption: The entire surface is covered by exostoses, except for the smooth area just posterior to the border of the auricular surface that is excluded from the scoring area. (ID# 1369)
Scoring locations of the posterior exostoses.

traits.title: Pubic symphyseal collar (left)
traits.location: Immediately anterior to the ventral margin of the pubic symphysis
notes: A collar should not be confused with the small ligamentous ossifications that often form on the anterior pubic surface near the symphyseal margin. To be scored as present, the ossifications must be at the same level as the symphyseal face for >= 10mm.
Care should be taken not to confuse the collar with rim breakdown, because the collar can appear to be the dominate (most noticeable) feature in this area.

When there is a ventral hiatus, the collar is still located anterior to the symphyseal face; it should not be confused with the face's margin. There is stypically a relatively deep depression between the anteriorly located collar and the posteriorly located dorsal demiface (that is because the majority of the ventral rampart never formed in this area).

scores.title: absent
scores.description: There is no extra bony growth or, if present, it is < 10mm long.

scores.title: collar
scores.description:
Extra extra bony growth with the appearance of ossified ligaments anterior and parallel to the ventral border of the symphyseal face that extends for >= 10mm. The ossification can be continuous or in multiple segments of several millimeters that collectively sum to >= 10mm.

The bony growth usually extends inferiorly from the superior ventral part of the symphyseal face, but can be present elsewhere along the ventral border. The ossification must be at the same height as a plane defined by the symphyseal face, and is separated from the face by a narrow groove.

In other words, moving anteriorly from the symphyseal face, one would encounter the ventral plateau, the anterior symphyseal margin (typically marked by a rim or its breakdown), a narrow channel, and finally the collar.

images.title: Collar
images.caption: The left collar extends only along the superior one-third of the joint. (ID# 2488)

images.title: Collar
images.caption: The collar extends along the entire ventral edge. (ID# 2460)

images.title: Collar
images.caption: In rare cases, the collar extends onto the symphyseal face. (ID# 2661)

traits.title: Symphyseal relief (left)
traits.location: The entire symphyseal face.

scores.title: billows
scores.description: Clearly visible and discrete elevations, from sharply crested ridges to low rounded hills, cover the most of the surface. The overall impression of the symphyseal face is one of a series of parallel low ridges (billows).

images.title: Billows
images.caption: Soft shallow billows cover the majoirty of the surface. (ID# 2738)

images.title: Billows
images.caption: Pubic symphysis in direct light. With appropriate lighting it is possible to see that the majority of the surface is covered in low rounded billows. (ID# 2739)

images.title: Billows
images.caption: Pubic symphysis in angled light. With appropriate lighting it is possible to see that the majority of the surface is covered in low rounded billows. (ID# 2739)

scores.title: residual
scores.description: The overall impression is that the symphyseal face is flat, but at least two consecutive billows are present. The residual billows are often barely visible, being only slightly elevated above the symphyseal face. They are often hard to detect except in good light and upon close examination.

images.title: Residual
images.caption: At least two consecutive billows are present in the inferior portion of the symphyseal face (arrows). Image reversed. (ID# 2174)

images.title: Residual
images.caption: Two consecutive billows are present in the inferior portion of the symphyseal face (arrows). (ID# 1800)

images.title: Residual
images.caption: Residual billows on an otherwise young-looking pubic face. (ID# 1843)

scores.title: flat/irregular
scores.description: At most one billow is present. A flat or slightly recessed face can be surrounded by a well-developed rim. Alternatively, the face can be marred by deep pits, small sharp exostoses, or both. Togther they give the surface an irregular, disfigured appearance. Often a flat or irregular face is defined by the rim and breakdown stage of the ventral and dorsal margin.

images.caption: The relief of the entire symphyseal face is scored.

traits.title: Superior protuberance (left)
traits.location: The superior part of the symphyseal face.

scores.title: serrated (no protuberance)
scores.description: When no protuberance is present (serrated), billowing is present in the superior part of the symphyseal face and there are no signs of a bony protuberance,

scores.title: knob (early protuberance)
scores.description: A distinct bony knob of variable dimensions with well-defined margins is visible in the superior part of the symphyseal face. It projects above the plane(s) defined by the immediately adjacent symphyseal face (the dorsal demiface, ventral beveled area, or both). The surface of the bony protuberance is typically smooth to fine grained.

images.title: Knob
images.caption: Lateral (a) and posterior (b) views. The superior protuberance has only recently formed. The edges are sharp and the knob of bone looks as though it could easily be removed from the surface. (ID# 1990)

images.title: Knob
images.caption: Lateral view of a small ossific nodule forming on the superior portion of the pubic symphysis. (ID# 2247)

images.title: Knob
images.caption: Posterior-oblique view of a small ossific nodule forming on the superior portion of the pubic symphysis. (ID# 2247)

images.title: Knob
images.caption: Both a knob and forming ventral rampart are present. (ID# 2015)

scores.title: flat (late protuberance, integrated)
scores.description: The superior part of the symphyseal face shows little to no sign of a low bony elevation. This stage, the absence of a raised area, is distinguishable from early because the superior portion of the symphyseal face is flat, not the ridge-and-valley surface (rarely an entirely beveled surface) typical of the initial early stage.

images.title: Flat
images.caption: Lateral (a) and oblique (b) views of a borderline case. The knob-like ossification on the superior part of the pubis is becoming integrated into the symphyseal face. Once this occurs, the face is considered flat. (ID# 1843)

images.title: Flat
images.caption: Lateral view of the a pubic symphysis. The borders of the knob are now smooth and integrated into the symphyseal face and surrounding rim. (ID# 1800)

images.title: Flat
images.caption: Lateral-oblique view of the a pubic symphysis. The borders of the knob are now smooth and integrated into the symphyseal face and surrounding rim. (ID# 1800)

images.title: Flat
images.caption: Posterior-oblique view of the a pubic symphysis. The borders of the knob are now smooth and integrated into the symphyseal face and surrounding rim. (ID# 1800)

images.title: Flat
images.caption: The superior portion of the pubic face is completely flat. (ID# 1571)

images.title: Flat
images.caption: The irregular ossification in the superior portion of the pubic face should be not confused with a superior protuberance. The bone is irregular and the margins are integrated into the pubic face. (ID# 2239)
Location of the superior protuberance.

traits.title: Ventral symphyseal margin (left)
traits.location: Ventral margin of the pubic symphysis.
notes: Occasionally a gap will remain in the superior half of the ventral margin at the completion of rampart formation (ventral hiatus). The ventral hiatus should not be confused with breakdown.
Care must be taken to distinguish antemortem degeneration -- that is, true breakdown -- from postmortem damage. The latter, of course, can render the bone unscorable if it is extensive.

scores.title: serrated or beveled
scores.description: The ventral rampart has not yet started to form (serrated or beveled). The ventral part of the symphyseal face is either covered with ridges and furrows or is in the process of flattening (beveling) ventrally. In either case, no distinct outgrowths of bone that ultimately form the ventral rampart are present.

scores.title: rampart (forming or complete)
scores.description: The rampart is either in the process of forming or is complete, but 10mm of rim has not formed. When forming, the rampart extends from one or both ends of the symphysis. It often resembles a roll of well-chewed gum stuck on the ventral edge of the symphyseal face. The complete rampart presents an uninterrupted flat surface from the dorsal to ventral margins of the symphyseal face (see note about the ventral hiatus).

images.title: Rampart
images.caption: Lateral (a) and oblique (b) views of a ventral rampart in an early stage of ossification. Rampart formation often begins in the superior portion of the symphysis. (ID# 2724)

images.title: Rampart
images.caption: The rampart is forming. (ID# 2247)

images.title: Rampart
images.caption: The rampart is nearing completion. (ID# 2174)

images.title: Rampart
images.caption: The rampart is essentially complete. (ID# 2015)

scores.title: rim
scores.description: A narrow, sharp to irregular bony elevation (rim) >= 10mm in length bordering a slightly depressed to irregular symphyseal face must be present. The rim can be either a continuous ridge of bone or several segments, as long as 10mm in total of elevated border is present. The rim's crest can be low and rounded, or narrow and sharp. A ventral rim is always formed on top of a completed ventral rampart (exlcuding any hiatus).

images.title: Rim
images.caption: More than 10mm of raised, regular rim extends along the ventral edge of the symphyseal face. The rim occurs on an otherwise billowed face. (ID# 2738)

scores.title: BD (breakdown)
scores.description: Breakdown of the ventral margin is indicated by pitting and an erosion of the rim. The breakdown of the ventral margin must exceed 10mm (either in one spot, or when two or more areas of erosion are combined) to be scored as present.

images.title: Breakdown
images.caption: The rim along most of the ventral border is porous and irregular. (ID# 1571)
Location of the ventral margin.

traits.title: Dorsal symphyseal margin (left)
traits.location: Ventral margin of the pubic symphysis.
notes: In females, dorsally located characteristics can be partly or entirely obscured by large postpartum, or parity, pits. Antemortem destruction attributable to large parity pits in femals that undercuts the dorsal margin is not considered breakdown in the sense of the term as used here. In most cases, such specimens cannot be scored propertly. When that occurs, the component is simply missing data.
Care must be taken to distinguish antemortem degeneration of the  margin from postmortem damage, which is of no concern.

scores.title: serrated
scores.description: Ridges and furrows typical of pronounced billowing extend uninterrupted into the edge of the bone.

images.title: Serrated
images.caption: Lateral (a), oblique (b), and posterior (c) views of a serrated dorsal margin. The billows cut deeply into the dorsal margin, which gives the appearance of a serrated knife blade. (ID# 2199)

scores.title: flattened
scores.description: A well-defined area >= 10mm long is present where the symphyseal face meets the dorsal margin, but >= 10mm of rim is not present. Flattening usually starts in the superior part of the dorsal demiface; the remainder of the margin has the ridge and valley configuration typical of a youthful symphyseal face. This flattening eventually extends along the entire symphyseal face where it meets the dorsal margin. A small area at the inerior end of the dorsal margin occasionally retains an undulating appearance.

scores.title: rim
scores.description: An elevated rim demarcates a flat or, infrequently, an irregular face. The rim projects slightly above the symphyseal face, and its crest can be blunt or sharp. The rim does not have to extend along the entire dorsal margin to be scored as present, but it must be >= 10mm long. The 10mm rule pertains to either a continuous rim or discontinuous segments that together sum to that length. A rim typically develops first along the superior part of the dorsal margin. It can, however, occur anywhere along the dorsal margin.

images.title: Rim
images.caption: More than 10mm of raised, regular rim extends along the dorsal edge of the symphyseal face. The rim occurs on an otherwise billowed face. (ID# 2738)

scores.title: breakdown
scores.description: The dorsal margin where the rim located shows evidence of breakdown when pitting and erosion of the edge of the pubic symphysis is >=10mm long. Breakdown must be >=10mm long either in one spot or when two or more areas of erosion are combine.

images.title: Breakdown
images.caption: The dorsal edge of this pubic face shows breakdown as both (a) porosity and (b) and irregular rim. The breakdown extends along essentially the entire length of the joint. (ID# 1571)
Location of the dorsal margin.

traits.location: Immediately anterior to the ventral margin of the pubic symphysis
notes: A collar should not be confused with the small ligamentous ossifications that often form on the anterior pubic surface near the symphyseal margin. To be scored as present, the ossifications must be at the same level as the symphyseal face for >= 10mm.
Care should be taken not to confuse the collar with rim breakdown, because the collar can appear to be the dominate (most noticeable) feature in this area.

When there is a ventral hiatus, the collar is still located anterior to the symphyseal face; it should not be confused with the face's margin. There is stypically a relatively deep depression between the anteriorly located collar and the posteriorly located dorsal demiface (that is because the majority of the ventral rampart never formed in this area).

traits.title: Dorsal symphyseal margin (right)
traits.location: Ventral margin of the pubic symphysis.
notes: In females, dorsally located characteristics can be partly or entirely obscured by large postpartum, or parity, pits. Antemortem destruction attributable to large parity pits in femals that undercuts the dorsal margin is not considered breakdown in the sense of the term as used here. In most cases, such specimens cannot be scored propertly. When that occurs, the component is simply missing data.
Care must be taken to distinguish antemortem degeneration of the  margin from postmortem damage, which is of no concern.

scores.title: serrated
scores.description: Ridges and furrows typical of pronounced billowing extend uninterrupted into the edge of the bone.

images.title: Serrated
images.caption: Lateral (a), oblique (b), and posterior (c) views of a serrated dorsal margin. The billows cut deeply into the dorsal margin, which gives the appearance of a serrated knife blade. (ID# 2199)

scores.title: flattened
scores.description: A well-defined area >= 10mm long is present where the symphyseal face meets the dorsal margin, but >= 10mm of rim is not present. Flattening usually starts in the superior part of the dorsal demiface; the remainder of the margin has the ridge and valley configuration typical of a youthful symphyseal face. This flattening eventually extends along the entire symphyseal face where it meets the dorsal margin. A small area at the inerior end of the dorsal margin occasionally retains an undulating appearance.

scores.title: rim
scores.description: An elevated rim demarcates a flat or, infrequently, an irregular face. The rim projects slightly above the symphyseal face, and its crest can be blunt or sharp. The rim does not have to extend along the entire dorsal margin to be scored as present, but it must be >= 10mm long. The 10mm rule pertains to either a continuous rim or discontinuous segments that together sum to that length. A rim typically develops first along the superior part of the dorsal margin. It can, however, occur anywhere along the dorsal margin.

images.title: Rim
images.caption: More than 10mm of raised, regular rim extends along the dorsal edge of the symphyseal face. The rim occurs on an otherwise billowed face. (ID# 2738)

scores.title: breakdown
scores.description: The dorsal margin where the rim located shows evidence of breakdown when pitting and erosion of the edge of the pubic symphysis is >=10mm long. Breakdown must be >=10mm long either in one spot or when two or more areas of erosion are combine.

images.title: Breakdown
images.caption: The dorsal edge of this pubic face shows breakdown as both (a) porosity and (b) and irregular rim. The breakdown extends along essentially the entire length of the joint. (ID# 1571)
Location of the dorsal margin.
